summary: This is the transcript of a court hearing before Judge Richard M. Berman regarding the government's motion to dismiss the indictment against Jeffrey Epstein following his death in custody. The hearing includes arguments from prosecutors, defense attorneys, and extensive victim impact statements from numerous women who describe being sexually abused and trafficked by Epstein and his associates.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein found dead in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). The medical examiner's conclusion was suicide by hanging, but defense attorneys question this and suggest foul play.

events.title: Court Hearing on Motion to Dismiss
events.description: Hearing before Judge Berman on the government's motion to dismiss the indictment (19 CR 490) due to Epstein's death. Victims give impact statements.

events.title: Previous Incident at MCC
events.description: Mentioned as a prior incident where Epstein was alleged to have attempted suicide, prompting judicial inquiry.

events.title: Florida Investigation and NPA
events.description: The prior Florida investigation of Epstein that resulted in a Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA), which defense attorneys argue should have precluded the New York prosecution.

locations: United States District Court, Southern District of New York
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein died by apparent suicide in his MCC cell on August 10, 2019, while awaiting trial on sex trafficking charges.
The government moved to dismiss the indictment based on the legal principle of abatement, which voids proceedings upon a defendant's death before conviction.
Judge Berman held a public hearing to promote transparency and allow victims to speak, citing the Crime Victims' Rights Act.
Multiple victims gave detailed, emotional statements describing being recruited, sexually abused, and trafficked by Epstein, often naming Ghislaine Maxwell as a key recruiter and accomplice.

Defense attorneys raised serious doubts about the official suicide conclusion, citing broken neck bones more consistent with homicide, malfunctioning surveillance tapes, and deplorable conditions at the MCC.
